div.head: SALE OF CREEDS The distinction between the personified creeds or philosophies here offered for sale, and their various founders or principal exponents, is but loosely kept up. Not only do most of the creeds bear the names of their founders, but some are even credited with their physical peculiarities and their personal experiences.
Zeus. Hermes. Pythagoras. Diogenes. Heraclitus. Socrates. Chrysippus. Democritus Several Dealers. Scepticism. Creeds

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Now get those benches straight there, and make the place fit to be seen. Bring up the lots, one of you, and put them in line. Give them a rub up first, though; we must have them looking their best, to attract bidders. Hermes, you can declare the sale-room open, and a welcome to all comers.—For Sale! A varied assortment of Live Creeds. Tenets of every description—Cash on delivery; or credit allowed on suitable security.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Here they come, swarming in. No time to lose; we must not keep them waiting.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Well, let us begin.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: What are we to put up first?

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: The Ionic fellow, with the long hair. He seems a showy piece of goods.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Step up, Pythagoreanism, and show yourself.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Now here is a creed of the first water. Who bids for this handsome article? What gentleman says Superhumanity? Harmony of the Universe! Transmigration of souls! Who bids? First Dealer. He looks all right. And what can he do?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Magic, music, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, jugglery. Prophecy in all its branches,

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Can I ask him some questions?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Ask away, and welcome.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Where do you come from?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Samos.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Where did you get your schooling?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: From the sophists in Egypt.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: If I buy you, what will you teach me?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Nothing. I will remind you.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Remind me?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: But first I shall have to cleanse your soul of its filth.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Well, suppose the cleansing process complete. How is the reminding done?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: We shall begin with a long course of silent contemplation. Not a word to be spoken for five years.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: You would have been just the creed for Croesus’s son! But I have a tongue in my head; I have no ambition to be a statue. And after the five years’ silence?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: You will study music and geometry.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: A charming recipe!’ The way to be wise: learn the guitar.

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Next you will learn to count.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: I can do that already.

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Let me hear you.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: One, two, three, four,—

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: There you are, you see. Four (as you call it) is ten. Four the perfect triangle. Four the oath of our school.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Now by Four, most potent Four!—higher and holier mysteries than these I never heard.

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Then you will learn of Earth, Air, Fire, and Water; their action, their movement, their shapes.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Have Fire and Air and Water shapes?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Clearly. That cannot move which lacks shape and form. You will also find that God is a number; an intelligence; a harmony.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: You surprise me.

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: More than this, you have to learn that you yourself are not the person you appear to be.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: What, I am some one else, not the I who am speaking to you?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: You are that you now: but you have formerly inhabited another body, and borne another name. And in course of time you will change once more.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Why then I shall be immortal, and take one shape after another?

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: But enough of this, And now what is your diet?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Of living things I eat none. All else I eat, except beans.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: And why no beans? Do you dislike them?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: No. But they are sacred things. Their nature is a mystery. Consider them first in their generative aspect; take a green one and peel it, and you will see what I mean. Again, boil one and expose it to moonlight for a proper number of nights, and you have—blood. What is more, the Athenians use beans to vote with.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: Admirable! A very feast of reason. Now just strip, and let me see what you are like. Bless me, here is a creed with a golden thigh! He is no mortal, he is a God. I must have him at any price. What do you start him at?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Forty pounds.

sp.speaker: First Dealer
sp.p: He is mine for forty pounds,

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Take the gentleman’s name and address.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: He must come from Italy, I should think; Croton or Tarentum, or one of the Greek towns in those parts. But he is not the only buyer. Some three hundred of them have clubbed together.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: They are welcome to him. Now up with the next.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: What about yonder grubby PontianSee Diogenes in Notes.?

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Yes, he will do.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: You there with the wallet and cloak; come along, walk round the room. Lot No.2, A most sturdy and valiant creed, free-born. What offers?

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Hullo, Mr. Auctioneer, are you going to sell a free man?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: That was the idea

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Take care, he may have you up for kidnapping. This might be matter for the Areopagus.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Oh, he would as soon be sold as not. He feels just as free as ever.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: But what is one to do with such a dirty fellow? He is a pitiable sight. One might put him to dig perhaps, or to carry water.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: That he can do and more. Set him to guard your house, and you will find him better than any watch-dog.— They call him Dog for short.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Where does he come from? and what is his method?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: He can best tell you that himself.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: I don’t like his looks. He will probably snarl if I go near him, or take a snap at me, for all I know. See how he lifts his stick, and scowls; an awkward-looking customer!

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Don’t be afraid. He is quite tame.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Tell me, good fellow, where do you come from?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Everywhere.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: What does that mean?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: It means that I am a citizen of the world.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: And your model?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Heracles.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Then why no lion’s-skin? You have the orthodox club.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: My cloak is my lion’s-skin. Like Heracles, I live in a state of warfare, and my enemy is Pleasure; but unlike him I am a volunteer. My purpose is to purify humanity.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: A noble purpose. Now what do I understand to be your strong subject?. What is your profession?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: The liberation of humanity, and the treatment of the” passions, In short, I am the prophet of Truth and Candour.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Well, prophet; and if I buy you, how shall you handle my case?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I shall commence operations by stripping off your superfluities, putting you into fustian, and leaving you closeted with Necessity. Then I shall give you a course of hard labour. You will sleep on the ground, drink water, and fill your belly as best you can, Have you money? ‘Take my advice and throw it into the sea. With wife and children and country you will not concern yourself; there will be no more of that nonsense. You will exchange your present home for a sepulchre, a ruin, or a tub. What with lupines and close-written tomes, your knapsack will never be empty; and you will vote yourself happier than any king. Nor will you esteem it any inconvenience, if a flogging or a turn of the rack should fall to your lot.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: How! Am I a tortoise, a lobster, that I should be flogged and feel it not?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: You will take your cue from Hippolytus; mutatis mutandis.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: ‘The heart may burn, the tongue knows nought thereof’Hippolytus (in Euripides’s play of that name) is reproached with having broken an oath, and thus defends himself; ‘The tongue hath sworn: the heart knew nonght thereof.’

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p:
‘The heart may burn, the tongue knows nought thereof’Hippolytus (in Euripides’s play of that name) is reproached with having broken an oath, and thus defends himself; ‘The tongue hath sworn: the heart knew nonght thereof.’
Above all, be bold, be impudent; distribute your abuse impartially to king and commoner. They will admire your spirit. You will talk the Cynic jargon with the true Cynic snarl, scowling as you walk, and walking as one should who scowls; an epitome of brutality. Away with modesty, good-nature, and forbearance. Wipe the blush from your cheek for ever. Your hunting-ground will be the crowded city. You will live alone in its midst, holding communion with none, admitting neither friend nor guest; for such would undermine your power. Scruple not to perform the deeds of darkness in broad daylight: select your love-adventures with a view to the public entertainment: and finally, when the fancy takes you, swallow a raw cuttle-fish, and die. Such are the delights of Cynicism.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: Oh, vile creed! Monstrous creed! Avaunt!

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: But look you, it is all so easy; it is within every man’s reach. No education is necessary, no nonsensical argumentation. I offer you a short cut to Glory. You may be the merest clown—cobbler, fishmonger, carpenter, money-changer; yet there is nothing to prevent your becoming famous. Given brass and boldness, you have only to learn to wag your tongue with dexterity.

sp.speaker: Second Dealer
sp.p: All this is of no use to me. But I might make a sailor or a gardener of you at a pinch; that is, if you are to be had cheap. Three-pence is the most I can give.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: He is yours, to have and to hold. And good riddance to the brawling foul-mouthed bully. He is a slanderer by wholesale.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Now for the Cyrenaic, the crowned and purple-robed.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Attend please, gentlemen all. A most valuable article, this, and calls for a long purse.’ Look at him, A sweet thing in creeds. A creed for a king. Has any gentleman a use for the Lap of Luxury? Who bids?:

sp.speaker: Third Dealer
sp.p: Come and tell me what you know. If you are a practical creed, I will have you.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Please not to worry him with questions, sir. He is drunk, and cannot answer; his tongue plays him tricks, as you see.

sp.speaker: Third Dealer
sp.p: And who in his senses would buy such an abandoned reprobate? How he smells of scent! And how he slips and staggers about! Well, you must speak for him, Hermes. What can he do? What is his line?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Well, for any gentleman who is not strait-laced, who loves a pretty girl, a bottle, and a jolly companion, he is the very thing. He is also a past master in gastronomy, and a connoisseur in voluptuousness generally. He was educated at Athens, and has served royalty in SicilySee Aristippus in Notes., where he had a very good character. Here are his principles in a nutshell: Think the worst of things: make the most of things: get all possible pleasure out of things.

sp.speaker: Third Dealer
sp.p: You must look for wealthier purchasers. My purse is not equal to such a festive creed.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Zeus, this lot seems likely to remain on our hands.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Put it aside, and up with another. Stay, take the pair from Abdera and Ephesus; the creeds of Smiles and Tears. They shall make one lot.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Come forward, you two. Lot No. 4. A superlative pair. The smartest brace of creeds on our catalogue.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: Zeus! What a difference is here! One of them does nothing but laugh, and the other might be at a funeral; he is all tears—You there! what is the joke?

sp.speaker: Democritus
sp.p: You ask? You and your affairs are all one vast joke.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: So! You laugh at us? Our business is a toy?

sp.speaker: Democritus
sp.p: It is. There is no taking it seriously. All is vanity. Mere interchange of atoms in an infinite void.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: Your vanity is infinite, if you like. Stop that laughing, you rascal.—

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: And you, my poor fellow, what are you crying for? I must see what I can make of you.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: I am thinking, friend, upon human affairs; and well may I weep and lament, for the doom of all is sealed. Hence my compassion and my sorrow. For the present, I think not of it; but the future!—the future is all bitterness. Conflagration and destruction of the world. I weep to think that nothing abides, All things are whirled together in confusion. Pleasure and pain, knowledge and ignorance, great and small; up and down they go, the playthings of Time.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: And what is Time?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: A child; and plays at draughts and blindman’s-buff.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: And men?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Are mortal Gods.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: And Gods?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Immortal men.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: So! Conundrums, fellow? Nuts to crack? You are a very oracle for obscurity.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Your affairs do not interest me.

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: No one will be fool enough to bid for you at that rate.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Young and old, him that bids and him that bids not, a murrain seize you all!

sp.speaker: Fourth Dealer
sp.p: A sad case. He will be melancholy mad before long. Neither of these is the creed for my money.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: No one bids.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Next lot.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: The Athenian there? Old Chatterbox?

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Come forward!—A good sensible creed this. Who buys Holiness?

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Let me see. What are you good for?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I teach the art of love.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: A likely bargain for me! I want a tutor for my young Adonis.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
And could he have a better? The love I teach is of.
the spirit, not of the flesh. Under my roof, be sure, a boy will come to no harm.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Very unconvincing that. A teacher of the art of love, and never meddle with anything but the spirit? Never use the opportunities your office gives you?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now by Dog and Plane-tree, it is as I say!

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Heracles! What strange Gods are these?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, the Dog is a God, I suppose? Is not Anubis made much of in Egypt? Is there not a Dog-star in Heaven, and a Cerberus in the lower world?

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Quite so. My mistake. Now what is your manner of life?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I live in a city of my own building; I make my own laws, and have a novel constitution of my own.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: I should like to hear some of your statutes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You shall hear the greatest of them all. No woman shall be restricted to one husband. Every man who likes is her husband.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: What! Then the laws of adultery are clean swept away?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I should think they were! and a world of hair-splitting with them.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: And what do you do with the handsome boys?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: ‘Their kisses are the reward of merit, of noble and spirited actions.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Unparalleled generosity!—And now, what are the main features of your philosophy?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Ideas and types of things. All things that you see, the earth and all that is upon it, the sea, the sky,—each has its counterpart in the invisible world.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: And where are they?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nowhere. Were they anywhere, they were not what they are.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: I see no signs of these ‘types’ of yours.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Of course not; because you are spiritually blind. I see the counterparts of all things; an invisible you, an invisible me; everything is in duplicate.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Come, such a shrewd and lynx-eyed creed is worth a bid. Let me see. What do you want for him?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Five hundred.

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Done with you. Only I must settle the bill another day.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: What name?

sp.speaker: Fifth Dealer
sp.p: Dion; of Syracuse.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Take him, and much good may he do you. Now I want Epicureanism. Who offers for Epicureanism? He isa disciple of the laughing creed and the drunken creed, whom we were offering just now. But he has one extra accomplishment— impiety. For the rest, a dainty, lickerish creed.

sp.speaker: Sixth Dealer
sp.p: What price?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Eight pounds.

sp.speaker: Sixth Dealer
sp.p: Here you are. By the way, you might let me know what he likes to eat.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Anything sweet. Anything with honey in it. Dried figs are his favourite dish.

sp.speaker: Sixth Dealer
sp.p: That is all right. We will get in a supply of Carian fig-cakes,

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Call the next lot. Stoicism; the creed of the sorrowful countenance, the close-cropped creed.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Ah yes, several customiers, I fancy, are on the look-out for him. Virtue incarnate! The very quintessence of creeds! Who is for universal monopoly?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: How are we to understand that?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Why, here is monopoly of wisdom, monopoly of beauty, monopoly of courage, monopoly of justice. Sole king, sole orator, sole legislator, sole millionaire.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: And I suppose sole cook, sole tanner, sole carpenter, and all that?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Presumably.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Regard me as your purchaser, good fellow, and tell me all about yourself. I dare say you think it rather hard to be sold for a slave?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Not at all. These things are beyond our control. And what is beyond our control is indifferent.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: I don’t see how you make that out.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: What! Have you yet to learn that of indifferentia some are praepostta and others rejecta?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Still I don’t quite see.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: No; how should you? You are not familiar with our terms. You lack the comprebensio vist. The earnest student of logic knows this and more than this. He understands the nature of subject, predicate, and contingent, and the distinctions between them.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Now in Wisdom’s name, tell me, pray, what is a predicate? what is a contingent? ‘There is a ring about those words that takes my fancy.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: With all my heart. A man lame in one foot knocks that foot accidentally against a stone, and gets a cut. Now the man is subject to lameness; which is the predicate. And the cut is a contingency.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Oh, subtle! What else can you tell me?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: I have verbal involutions, for the better hampering, crippling, and muzzling of my antagonists. This is performed by the use of the far-famed syllogism.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Syllogism! I warrant him a tough customer.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Take a case. You have a child?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Well, and what if I have?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p:
A crocodile catches him as he wanders along the bank of a river, and promises to restore him to you, if you will first
guess correctly whether he means to restore him or not. Which are you going to say?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: A difficult question. I don’t know which way I should get him back soonest. In Heaven’s hame, answer for me, and save the child before he is eaten up.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Ha, ha. I will teach you far other things than that.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: For instance?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: There is the ‘Reaper.’ There is the ‘Rightful Owner.’ Better still, there is the ‘Electra’ and the ‘Man in the Hood.’

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Who was he? and who was Electra?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: She was the Electra, the daughter of Agamemnon, to whom the same thing was known and unknown at the same time. She knew that Orestes was her brother: yet when he stood before her she did not know (until he revealed himself) that her brother was Orestes. As to the Man in the Hood, he will surprise you considerably. Answer me now: do you know your own father?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Well now, if I present to you a man in a hood, shall you know him? eh?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Well, but the Man in the Hood is your father. You don’t know the Man in the Hood. Therefore you don’t know your own father.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Why, no. But if I take his hood off, I shall get at the facts. Now tell me, what is the end of your philosophy? What happens when you reach the goal of virtue?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: In regard to things external, health, wealth, and the like, I am then all that Nature intended me to be. But there is much previous toil to be undergone. You will first sharpen your eyes on minute manuscripts, amass commentaries, and get your bellyful of outlandish terms. Last but not least, it is forbidden to be wise without repeated doses of hellebore.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: All this is exalted and magnanimous to a degree. But what am I to think when I find that you are also the creed of cent-per-cent, the creed of the usurer? Has be swallowed his hellebore? is be made perfect in virtue?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Assuredly. On none but the wise man does usury sit well, Consider. His is the art of putting two and two together, and usury is the art of putting interest together. The two are evidently connected, and one as much as the other is the prerogative of the true believer; who, not content, like common men, with simple interest, will also take interest upon interest. For interest, as you are probably aware, is of two kinds. There is simple interest, and there is its offspring, compound interest. Hear Syllogism on the subject. ‘If I take simple interest, I shall also take compound. But I shall take simple interest: therefore I shall take compound.’

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: And the same applies to the fees you take from your youthful pupils? None but the true believer sells virtue for a fee?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Quite right. I take the fee in my pupil’s interest, not because I want it. The world is made up of diffusion and accumulation. I accordingly practise my pupil in the former, and myself in the latter.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: But it ought to be the other way. The pupil ought to accumulate, and you, ‘sole millionaire,’ ought to diffuse.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Ha! you jest with me? Beware of the shaft of insoluble syllogism.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: What harm can that do?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: It cripples; it ties the tongue, and turns the brain.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: It cripples; it ties the tongue, and turns the brain. Nay, I have but to will it, and you are stone this instant.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Stone! You are no Perseus, friend?

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: See here. A stone is a body?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Well, and an animal is a body?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: And you are an animal?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: I suppose I am.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: ‘Therefore you are a body. Therefore a stone.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Mercy, in Heaven’s name! Unstone me, and let me be flesh as heretofore.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: That is soon done. Back with you into flesh! Thus: Is every body animate?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Is a stone animate?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Now, you are a body?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: And an animate body?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chrysippus
sp.p: Then being animate, you cannot be a stone.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Ah! thank you, thank you. I was beginning to feel my limbs growing numb and solidifying like Niobe’s. Oh, I must have you. What’s to pay?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Fifty pounds.

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Here it is.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Are you sole purchaser?

sp.speaker: Seventh Dealer
sp.p: Not I. All these gentlemen here are going shares.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: A fine strapping lot of fellows, and will do the ‘Reaper’ credit.

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: Don’t waste time. Next lot,—the Peripatetic!

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Now, my beauty, now, Affluence! Gentlemen, if you want Wisdom for your money, here is a creed that comprises all knowledge.:

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: What is he like?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: He is temperate, good-natured, easy to get on with; and his strong point is, that he is twins,

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Why, he is one creed outside, and another inside. So remember, if you buy him, one of him is called Esoteric, and the other Exoteric.

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: And what has he to say for himself?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: He has to say that there are three kinds of good: spiritual, corporeal, circumstantial,

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: There’s something a man can understand. How much is he?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Eighty pounds.

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: Eighty pounds is a long price.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Not at all, my dear sir, not at all. You see, there is some money with him, to all appearance. Snap him up before it is too late. Why, from him you will find out in no time how long a gnat lives, to how many fathoms’ depth the sunlight penetrates the sea, and what an oyster’s soul is like.

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: Heracles! Nothing escapes him.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Ah, these are trifles. You should hear some of his more abstruse speculations, concerning generation and birth and the development of the embryo; and his distinction between man, the laughing creature, and the ass, which is neither a laughing nor a carpentering nor a shipping creature.

sp.speaker: Eighth Dealer
sp.p: Such knowledge is as useful as it is ornamental. Eighty pounds be it, then.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: He is yours,

sp.speaker: Zeus
sp.p: What have we left?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: There is Scepticism. Come along, Pyrrhias, and be put up. Quick’s the word. The attendance is dwindling; there will be small competition. Well, who buys Lot 9?

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: I. Tell me first, though, what do you know?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: But how’s that?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: There does not appear to me to de anything.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Are not we something?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: How do I know that?

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: And you yourself?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Of that I am still more doubtful.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Well, you are in a fix! And what have you got those scales for?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: I use them to weigh arguments in, and get them evenly balanced, They must be absolutely equal—not a feather-weight to choose between them; then, and not till then, can I make uncertain which is right.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: What else can you turn your hand to?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Anything; except catching a runaway.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: And why not that?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Because, friend, everything eludes my grasp.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: I believe you. A slow, lumpish fellow you seem to be. And what is the end of your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Ignorance. Deafness. Blindness.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: What! sight and hearing both gone?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: And with them judgement and perception, and all, in short, that distinguishes man from a worm.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: You are worth money!—What shall we say for him?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Four pounds.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Here it is, Well, fellow; so you are mine?

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: I doubt it.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Nay, doubt it not! You are bought and paid for.

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: It is a difficult case.... I reserve my decision.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Now, come along with me, like a good slave.

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: But how am I to know whether what you say is true?

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Ask the auctioneer. Ask my money. Ask the spectators.

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Spectators? But can we be sure there are any?

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Oh, V'll send you to the treadmill. That will convince you with a vengeance that I am your master.

sp.speaker: Scepticism
sp.p: Reserve your decision.

sp.speaker: Ninth Dealer
sp.p: Too late. It is given.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus
sp.p: Stop that wrangling and go with your purchaser. Gentlemen, we hope to see you here again to-morrow, when we shall be offering some lots suitable for plain men, artisans, and shopkeepers.
